Award.AwardTitle: A Framework for Maintaining Product Superiority by Designing Hardware That Protects Itself From Reverse Engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
A Framework for Maintaining Product Superiority by Designing Hardware that Protects Itself from Reverse Engineering

Proposal Number: 0800904
Christopher A. Mattson
Brent L. Adams

The research objective of this award is to develop a framework for designing consumer products that protect themselves from reverse engineering. Upon completion, designers will be able to create products that can be handled and examined by customers and competitors without disclosing the phenomena by which the products function, essentially protecting the device from reverse engineering. This will provide developers with the ability to maintain the competitive advantage that results from their hardware development efforts. The core of this research is the integration of three enabling design methodologies: (i) microstructure sensitive design, (ii) heterogeneous design, and (iii) embedded systems design. Advanced numerical and multiobjective optimization methods make possible the search for superior material properties and device geometry through the manipulation of numerous non-intuitive, non-traditional, design variables. Experiments will be used to validate the design approach.

If successful, the results of this research will provide a powerful new approach to product design with material considerations. This research can fundamentally change design and manufacturing paradigms in some industries. Because the material microstructure and associated manufacturing processes will be extremely difficult to reverse engineer, hardware secrets can be protected under the new framework. This will lead to the development of more advanced hardware, thus increasing the competitive technological and economical advantages enjoyed by the developing entity. This gives companies that struggle to compete with low cost overseas manufacturing a new value-added approach to design and manufacturing. The results of this research will be used as the basis for the development of educational modules for use in industry and academia which include reading packets, presentations, homework assignments and experiment descriptions. These will be distributed widely via the internet.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have developed a multidisciplinary, multi-scale, engineering design method for creating consumer products that are unusually difficult for competitors to reverse engineer – thereby enabling more protection for innovative technologies in consumer products. The new methodology allows innovators to create products that can be handled and examined by consumers and competitors without disclosing the phenomena by which the products function, essentially protecting them from reverse engineering.

The research team has discovered that a viable path to creating products that resist reverse engineering lies in designing the product at three disparate length scales. (i) At the micro scale, material microstructure (crystallographic orientation and dislocation distribution) is manipulated to improve product performance. (ii) At the meso scale, components are designed considering microstructure heterogeneity. And (iii) at the macro scale, the system is designed to meet consumer needs as enabled by the enhanced component design. By simultaneously controlling engineering variables at these different scales, the researchers have unlocked a rich design space wherein better performing designs are identified. A complex weave of product details across the different length scales is unusually difficult to discover under traditional reverse engineering techniques and is the basis for the new method.

The results of this research provide a powerful new approach to product design with material considerations. This research can fundamentally change design and manufacturing paradigms in some industries. Because the material microstructure and associated manufacturing processes are extremely difficult to reverse engineer, hardware secrets can be protected under the new framework. This will lead to the development of more advanced hardware, thus increasing the competitive technological and economical advantages enjoyed by the developing entity. This gives companies that struggle to compete with low cost overseas manufacturing a new value-added approach to design and manufacturing.

The research couples two otherwise distant, but critical, fields of study: product design and materials engineering. Methodologies that benefit from a highly coupled collaborative relationship between product designers and materials engineers would result in numerous otherwise untapped technologies. The research also provides an extended outlook on optimization methods in design, one that integrates size, shape, and micro-scale materials design.

Because the microstructure and associated manufacturing process are extremely difficult to discern, under the developments resulting from this research, design and manufacturing industries in the US can revert from its current trend toward commodity to the more welcomed state of asset. This gives companies that struggle to compete with low cost overseas manufacturing a new outlook on business and technology strategy – one that was previously out of reach. Rooted in this is the notion that because hardware secrets can be better protected under the new methodology, more advanced hardware will be developed, thus increasing the competitive technological and economical advantages enjoyed by the developing entity.
